â€‰ Kendall was spotted with a Kelly bag valued around $75K, and Kylie posed with a Birkin valued around $300,000 NEED TO KNOW KylieÂ andÂ Kendall JennerÂ are flaunting some very expensive handbags as they vacation in Saint-Tropez, France Kendall was spotted balancing an HermÃ¨s Kelly Doll Picto bag on her head as she took a shot, and Kylie shared a photo to Instagram posing with a Birkin 20 Sellier Neige White Faubourg House Alligator Bag The sisters have been vacationing in France just after attending Jeff Bezos' star-studded wedding in Venice, Italy KylieÂ andÂ Kendall JennerÂ are soaking up the sun on their French summer vacation â€” and flaunting some very expensive handbags. Over the Fourth of July weekend, the sisters were spotted out and about in Saint-Tropez, France. In a video shared to her friend and influencer Devon Lee Carlson's account on Saturday, July 5, Kendall, 29, could be seen sitting at a restaurant table wearing a polka-dot dress and taking a shot as she balanced a purse on her head. Eagle-eyed fans quickly pointed out that this wasn't any purse that the 818 Tequila founder was balancing on her head â€” the bag is a limited-edition yellow and white HermÃ¨s Kelly Doll Picto, according to Sotheby's, and the bag can easily fetch upwards of $75,000 on the resale market. Kendall Jenner. Kylie Jenner/Instagram In a post shared to German businessman and reality TV star Robert Geiss' Instagram, Kylie could be seen pulling off the same trick, balancing the Kelly bag on her head as she sipped a martini with a pair of sunglasses on her face. This wasn't the only designer bag the sisters have trotted out for their French vacation. In another Instagram post shared to 27-year-old Kylie's account on Sunday, July 6, the Kylie Cosmetics founder included some photos of her beach-ready outfits â€” one of which included a white knit bra, skirt and corset look. To complete her outfit, Kylie clutched a White Birkin Faubourg House Alligator Bag, which can fetch anywhere from $200K to upwards of $300K, according to Sotheby's. Kylie Jenner. Kylie Jenner/Instagram Other photos in the post included Kendall, Kylie and their group of friends watching Love Island USA on a tiny laptop, posing for a photo at a restaurant table, hopping into the ocean and looking out into the water from a boat at night. Kylie also showed off another outfit she paired with the Kelly bag, which featured a white cutout halter top and a matching bubble skirt â€” a custom look by Isabel Marant, perÂ Vogue â€” as well as a pair of slingback black heels. Never miss a story â€” sign up forÂ PEOPLE's free daily newsletterÂ to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offerâ€‹â€‹, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories. During a day of fun in the sun at Loulou Beach Club on Pampelonne Beach, the pair were previously photographed going out into the waves with their beach cover-ups still on. Kendall wore the same sheer black cap-sleeve minidress with white polka-dots, which showed a black string bikini underneath when wet. Her hair was pulled back in a half-up-half-down style that featured a middle part. To round out her beach day look, the 818 founder wore a pair of black sunshades. The siblings' trip with friends to Saint-Tropez comes just after they recently attendedÂ Jeff BezosÂ andÂ Lauren SÃ¡nchez's star-studded wedding in Venice, Italy. Kylie arrived to the billionaire couple's nuptials in a silvery blue corset gown, and Kendall wore a black mesh dress paired with 110 carats of Colombian emeralds by Lorraine Schwartz. Kendall, Kris and Kylie Jenner leave the Gritti Palace Hotel for a party on the third day of the wedding of US Amazon founder Jeff Bezos with Lauren Sanchez. Sisters Kim Kardashian andÂ KhloÃ© Kardashian, as well as family matriarchÂ Kris Jenner,Â were also in attendance in Italy. For the June 27 ceremony, the ladies took water taxis while in the Floating City, with the SKIMS mogul, 44, going glam in a black Versace dress with a V-neckline and a textured design at the bust and along the sides as well as a pair of dark sunglasses to round out her look. KhloÃ©, 41, also rocked a pair of black sunshades, though the Good American businesswoman chose pretty in pink over a dark-colored dress. Her strapless gown also touted a plunging neckline with subtle boning, teamed with a massive feather boa for added drama.

â€‰ DespiteÂ having never designed any jewelry or visited the island of Capri until recently, the iconoclastic artist Marina AbramoviÄ‡ has gamefully joined forces with Chantecler Capri. In what seems to have been one of the more al fresco approaches to sharing theÂ news of a collaboration, the island, which is located in the Gulf of NaplesÂ just a few nautical miles from the Peninsula of Sorrento, welcomed the artist late last month for a public event entitled â€œBreathing Rocks.â€ TheÂ Chantecler x Marina AbramoviÄ‡ capsule collection is inspired by AbramoviÄ‡'s art and the island's primordial forces. The preview initiative â€” held at the Tragara vista where the toweringÂ Faraglioni rocks rise from the seaÂ in the distance â€” didn't just have the municipal administration's support, Capri's Mayor Paolo Falco was on hand, as were its councilors Salvatore Ciuccio and Melania Esposito. They weren't just there to show some face time, but to relay, on behalf of the community, the value of the cultural dialogue that AbramoviÄ‡'s presence brought. The Serbian-born conceptual artist's body of work includes videos, soundscapes, installations, photographs and solo performances including the seminal â€œThe Artist Is Present.â€ During a three-month run at the Museum of Modern Art in New York in 2010, AbramoviÄ‡ sat unblinkingly every day, as thousands of strangers lined up to have the chance to stare back at her. Chantecler's creative director, Maria Elena Aprea, was responsible for corrallingÂ AbramoviÄ‡, with help from art directorÂ and stylist Andrea Lazzari and the Modern Art Museum of Shanghai's artistic directorÂ Shai Baitel. For â€œBreathing Rocks,â€ the artist sat down withÂ Baitel and journalist and author Cesare Cunaccia, whose books include â€œCapri Dolce Vita.â€ A Q&A session with attendees took place at the end of the program. During the conversation, the artist spoke of how she has explored areas that relate to art and design, but this was her first foray into jewelryÂ design in her decades-long career, Baitel said Monday. The Chantecler endeavor was â€œaÂ natural continuationâ€ of AbramoviÄ‡'s ['Transforming Energy'] exhibition at the Modern Art Museum in Shanghai, which dealt with stones, minerals and energy and which wound down in March, he said. In turn, the artist designed with Lazzari the conceptÂ of the three stones, which references the island's natural phenomenon of theÂ Faraglioni. Each stone is meantÂ to have its own energy, which is in line with the artist's design philosophy. Intent on extending theÂ philosophy about energy that she had used with Baitel in the MAM Shanghai show, AbramoviÄ‡ kept going back to their discussions about curating energy. â€œI said, 'We don't curate the physical. We curate the metaphysical.' She said, 'OK, so there's a great jeweler of theÂ necklaces, but the importance is the energy that the stones give you. Now you have this halo that is kind of a secret. It is part of the goodness that the stones bestow onÂ you.' It's curious because this is not an art exhibition, but it's a relative philosophy to what's behind the art,â€ Baitel said. More in Entertainment Accustomed to speaking with AbramoviÄ‡ several times a week and sometimes severalÂ times a day, Baitel said, â€œShe loves fashion. It's only been in the past year or two that she's speaking more about how fashion is part of what she does.â€ (As part of the endeavor, AbramoviÄ‡ receivedÂ a dress designed by Italian label Crida, which was created by its founders Cristina Parodi and Daniela Palazzi.) In the past, the artist hasÂ turned up at fashion shows for Prada, Versace, Jil Sander, MM6, Ferragamo and other brands. She once collaboratedÂ with Riccardo Tisci too on the art project that was entitled â€œContact.â€ Last year AbramoviÄ‡ debuted skin care and wellness products as part of the AbramoviÄ‡ Longevity Method and she joined forces with the ItalianÂ brand Massimo Dutti for Miami Art Week 2024. MoreÂ recently, she rolled out a NFT project with TAEX â€œMarina AbramoviÄ‡ Element.â€ Founded in 1947 by Pietro â€œChanteclerâ€Â Capuano, an heir to a family of theÂ Neapolitan jewelers, with his friend Salvatore Aprea, the brand started with one store onÂ Capri. Jet setters like Audrey Hepburn and Ingrid Bergman Rossellini were among the early fans. Aprea's heirsÂ Gabriele, along with his wife Teresa and sisters Maria Elena and Costanza, now run the business, which has headquarters in Milan and a production centerÂ in Valenza Po, an area known for its goldsmiths. Presented with collaborative opportunities all the time, AbramoviÄ‡ liked that Chantecler has such an elegant boutique on Capri, as well as for its reutation for being a brand for â€œpeople in-the-know like Jackie Kennedy, as opposed to being proliferated for the mass market,â€ Baitel said. â€œShe liked that it was unique like an original piece of art,â€Â he said. Due out inÂ September, the assortment includes a necklace, bracelet and earrings. Next year AbramoviÄ‡'s exhibition will debut at the Gallerie dell'Accademia, during the BiennaleÂ inÂ Venice. â€œShe will be turning 80 next year. And this is like the Oscars of the art world,â€Â Baitel added.

â€‰ Fiorucci Spring Summer 2026 backstage moments captured by Sohom Das for DSCENE   With a career spanning some of the most iconic names in Italian fashion, Versace, Giorgio Armani, Gucci, Givenchy, and Ferragamo, Francesca Murri has quietly shaped the visual language of contemporary luxury. In 2023, she took the creative helm at Fiorucci, the legendary Italian label founded in 1967 by Elio Fiorucci. Tasked with revitalizing a brand known for its irreverence and pop spirit, Murri has already presented four collections that pulse with energy, color, and optimism. Murri's approach to Fiorucci is equal parts reverence and reinvention. Drawing deeply from the house's rich archive, she reinterprets its iconic motifsâ€”lips, angels, hearts, through a modern, playful lens. Her debut collection, unveiled at Milan Fashion Week in September 2023, set the tone for her tenure: a vibrant celebration of joy, freedom, and creativity, all rooted in Fiorucci's signature DNA. The upcoming â€œ Beatittudo â€ FW25 collection continued this narrative, inspired by the pursuit of pure happiness and characterized by a bold palette that injects fresh energy into the brand. Under Francesca Murri, Fiorucci has become a platform for experimentation and dialogue, embracing collaborations with artists and emerging talents from across the creative spectrum. Her vision is about more than clothes; it's about fostering a community and spreading positive messages that resonate in today's world. By blending the brand's storied past with the needs and languages of modern society, Murri is ensuring Fiorucci's legacy remains as dynamic and relevant as ever. Below, Francesca Murri discusses with DSCENE's EIC Zarko Davinic her creative process, the role of Milan, the power of contrasts, and her hopes for Fiorucci's future post her Spring Summer 2026 runway show in Milan . Photo Â©Sohom Das   What does it mean for you and Fiorucci to present your collections in Milano every season? How does the city's unique energy influence your creative process? â€“ Milano is where Elio Fiorucci created everything and started dreaming. It's crucial for me to catch the spirit of the city and put it into a very international narrative. Influences come from everywhere in this place full of art. Piazza Fiorucci is described as a space where everyday reality and fantasy meet. How did you translate this concept into both the collection and the show's outdoor set design? â€“ For the collection I asked Janina Zais to work body painting and hair spraying the models to inject the cartoonish approach into the products. I also take inspiration, for the red pois dress, from the Walt Disney character Minnie. For the set design I wanted to use banners that represented the sky and road signs on the ground with totally invented and fantastic elements such as the angel shooting the arrow. The collection is full of contrasts, urban yet dreamlike, tender yet sensual. How do you approach balancing these opposing elements in your designs? â€“ I play very much with contrasts that are very crucial for the brand. When there's something basic I apply something unexpected in a very Fiorucci way. And also the contrast played through the association between products and faces is very important. Rock characters with chic products and the opposites work very well. Many pieces play with iconic Fiorucci motifs, like the lips, angels, and hearts, reimagined in playful, pop-art ways. What draws you to these symbols, and how do you keep them feeling fresh? â€“ I always start by defining the key pillars of the brand and based on the seasonal concept I focus on the ones that help me to push forward the concept. This season the pop, cartoonish approach influenced my way to characterize them. The slogan â€œMake Hearts Beat Againâ€ featured on accessories and tees is both affectionate and provocative. What message are you hoping to send with this phrase? â€“ In these uncertain moments in which everyone is a bit scared, I wanted send out a positive message by inviting people to make hearts beat again. An ode to love! Photo Â©Sohom Das   The collection uses a bold color palette and a mix of classic and innovative materials, from recycled PVC to Tyvek and glossy coatings. How do you decide which materials best express a new Fiorucci era? â€“ We usually search for innovative materials and this is very important to express the feelings I am having at the beginning of the creative process. The unexpected approach to the usage of the materials can create uniqueness. In a time when the fashion industry faces economic challenges and a looming recession, what do you believe will help brands like Fiorucci stay resilient and relevant? â€“ It's hard for the new projects to find a place in this tough and crowded market. I believe that Fiorucci can have a role in society by creating a platform for collaborations with emerging talents to generate very creative contents not only in fashion but also in art and music. Looking ahead, how do you see Fiorucci's identity evolving? What are your hopes for the brand, and for the industry? â€“ I see the project more mature season after season. I hope the market will get better soon to have more opportunities to reach our targeted clients throughout pop ups and stores and give them more chances to experience the brand. Discover all the Spring Summer 2026 Fiorucci collection looks by Francesca Murri on DSCENE . The post Francesca Murri Interview: Breathing New Life into Fiorucci appeared first on DSCENE .

â€‰ If recent fashion weeks are anything to go by, couture is locked in on India. From mukaish coats to the controversial Kohlapuri sandals, here's a round-up Paris and Milan Fashion Week Spring Summer 2026 made one thing very clear. Fashion's gaze is locked on India. Not the soft-focus version from a postcard or the usual token bindi or scarf. This time, it was more immersive. Textiles, embroidery, silhouettes, footwear, set design. India was threaded into the very core of the season. Okay, so this is not new Fashion has always turned to India for ideas. It is a long history dressed up as inspiration. For instance, Jean Paul Gaultier showed turbans, bindis, and sherwani jackets in his 2007 couture line. John Galliano pulled heavily from Mughal silhouettes during his Dior years. Karl Lagerfeld sent Chanel's MÃ©tiers d'Art to Mumbai back in 2012. The staging was theatrical. The embroidery was Indian. The credits were barely there. Dries Van Noten once said India was his textile dreamland. He was not alone. Fast fashion jumped in too. High street brands have churned out block prints, mirror work, paisley shawls, and even yoga pants with temple motifs. Little to no credit was given. Dior's shiny coat came at a cost One of the most talked-about pieces from Paris Fashion Week SS 26 came from Dior. A long silver coat, completely hand-embroidered using the Mukaish technique, shimmered its way into every major fashion feed. It was stunning. It also came with a story no one told. Mukaish is a painstaking craft that dates back to third-century Lucknow. It involves tiny flattened metal wires stitched into fabric, creating a constellation of dots that catch the light. Royalty once wore it. Today, barely a handful of skilled artisans still know how to make it right. That one Dior coat took twelve artisans over thirty days to finish. The coat's reported value was close to two hundred thousand dollars. But despite the effort and the heritage, the brand did not credit the embroidery technique or the artisans in the show notes. That silence drew instant heat from Indian designers, craft activists, and media. Prada's sandals were just not sandals Prada's menswear show in Milan SS26 made waves for all the wrong reasons. Among the slick tailoring and rich fabrics was a humble-looking sandal. Open-toe, flat sole, a leather toe-loop. Yes, we are talking about Kolhapuris. These are not just any shoes. They are traditional hand-made sandals crafted in Maharashtra for generations. They have been granted geographical indication status, which means their design is protected, legally linked to their region and community. Prada described them as â€œleather flat sandals.â€ That was it. No reference to Kolhapur. No mention of India. Nothing. The backlash was swift. The Maharashtra Chamber of Commerce raised formal concerns....

â€‰ India, July 8 -- The runways at the Milan and Paris Fashion Weeks made one thing very clear: fashion's gaze is turned to India. Even as questions around appropriation arose, India was threaded firmly into the core of the season, from textiles and textures, right down to the models and set design. Fashion has always turned to India for ideas. It is a long history dressed up as inspiration. For instance, Jean Paul Gaultier showed turbans, bindis, and sherwani jackets in his 2007 couture line. John Galliano pulled heavily from Mughal silhouettes during his Dior years. Karl Lagerfeld sent Chanel's Metiers d'Art to Mumbai back in 2012. The staging was theatrical. The embroidery was Indian. The credits were barely there. Dries Van Noten once said India was his textile dreamland. He was not alone. Fast fashion jumped in too. High street brands have churned out block prints, mirror work, paisley shawls, and even yoga pants with temple motifs. Little to no credit was given. Dior served up Paris Fashion Week's most talked-about pieces: a shimmering, mukaish-embroidered long coat. This art form dates back to third-century Lucknow and involves flattened metal wires stitched into fabric. Once worn by royalty, the Dior version (valued at close to 1.72 lakh) took twelve artisans and over thirty days to finish. However, the brand did not credit the technique or the artisans involved in its show notes, drawing flak from Indian designers and craft activists. Prada's menswear show in Milan SS26 made waves for all the wrong reasons. Among the slick tailoring and rich fabrics was a humble-looking sandal. Open-toe, flat sole, a leather toe-loop. Yes, we are talking about Kolhapuris. These are not just any shoes. They are traditional hand-made sandals crafted in Maharashtra for generations. They have been granted geographical indication status, which means their design is protected, legally linked to their region and community. Prada described them as "leather flat sandals." That was it. No reference to Kolhapur. No mention of India. Nothing. The backlash was swift. The Maharashtra Chamber of Commerce raised formal concerns. Indian designers called it out. Eventually, Prada issued a letter acknowledging the sandals were inspired by India and said they were open to future dialogue with Indian artisans. While global brands were fumbling with credits, Kartik Research arrived in Paris and flipped the script. The Delhi-based label presented a travelogue-like collection, accompanied by a visual essay titled, How to Make It in India. The brand also finally forayed into womenswear amid serious buzz. From textiles to silhouettes, each piece told a story of Indian craftsmanship, ranging from handlooms to hand-weaving and dyeing. Surfaces also told a story of heritage, with Jaipur rugs covering every inch of the set. Pharrell Williams's second menswear show for Louis Vuitton was another moment where Indian craft played a leading role. The runway was staged on Paris's oldest bridge, which was transformed into a snakes and ladders board. The set was designed by Indian architect Bijoy Jain and built using Indian marble, stone, and wood. The soundtrack was created in collaboration with A R Rahman. Palm trees, crystal-studded trunks, elephant motifs, and even a miniature autorickshaw bag nodded to Indian and South Asian culture. This was not an abstract reference. Louis Vuitton clearly credited the designers, artists, and inspiration behind the show. India's fashion week footprint did not end at fabric or set designs - models from India took centre stage at some of the biggest showcases. Walking for Hermes was Nakul Bhardwaj, who made headlines last year as the first Indian on the Versace runway. Meanwhile, Jainil Mehta made waves at Louis Vuitton, Saurang Sharma (pictured left) brought his quiet power to Issey Miyake and Shubham Vaidkar appeared in Giorgio Armani's presentation....

â€‰ Yea, usually the perfumes they're duping I can easily find the OG on outlet retailers for just as cheap or maybe $20 more...and those retailers have A+ ratings with the Better Business Bureau (I checked them all) that have been in business 20 years online - so they're NOT selling fakes. They're just not. Business go out of business all the time and have to auction off their authentic perfumes to outlet retailers, older perfumes stop selling, and they have to clear inventory for new perfumes, as well. I bought Versace Crystal Noir was $40 on ForeverLux since thats a 20 year old perfume - it hit outlet retailers like 17 years ago and they've done nothing but accumulate those perfumes. Then there are testers that are even cheaper. In fact, I've seen a Maison Alhambra VS Bombshell dupe selling for MORE on Amazon than the actual VS Bombshell on Fragrancenet/ForeverLux/Fragrancebuy(!) - which is usually in the links to your favorite perfume influencers on youtube where they earn a commission. So if it's good enough for them, the Better Business Bureau to give them an A+, and having never bought a fake from any of those 3 websites, it's good enough for me. There's no need to resort to these very, VERY cheaply made (and unhealthy) perfumes. I don't wanna breathe in that shit so strong all day that I can actually smell it! Ew! I'm done with cheap Lattafas and their umbrella brands after Minya dried down to smelling like Tupperware. Smelled so good at first and all the ingredients were covering the phthalates then in the 4th hour nothing but plastic left. Giving away my bottle with a health warning.

â€‰ Nicole Obarzanek - "Into Another World" Nicole Obarzanek Nicole Obarzanek "Toxic" music video Nicole Obarzanek Nicole Obarzanek, "Toxic" - cover art Nicole Obarzanek Redefines Dance - Pop Genres With Two Sensational New Music Video Releases - â€œInto Another Worldâ€ and â€œToxicâ€ Nicole's ability to convey raw emotion while commanding the stage is extraordinaryâ€ â€” Sahaj Ticotin, Los Angeles-based music producer LOS ANGELES, CA, UNITED STATES, July 8, 2025 /EINPresswire.com/ -- Nicole Obarzanek, the 14-year-old multi-talented prodigy from Dubai, is setting the global music scene ablaze with the release of two electrifying music videos for her singles â€œInto Another Worldâ€ and â€œToxic.â€ Born in Poland in 2010, and now a rising star in the UAE, Nicole's dynamic performances as a singer, dancer, actor, and model are showcased in these visually stunning videos, now streaming across YouTube, Apple Music, Spotify, and Anghami. â€œInto Another World,â€ produced by acclaimed Los Angeles-based producer Sahaj Ticotin, blends contemporary dance rhythms with orchestral elements, reflecting Nicole's rich musical heritage. The video, filmed across Dubai and Los Angeles at SoundStruck Studios and FIVE Hotel Music Studio, incorporates cutting-edge AI technology and futuristic visuals, elevating her artistry to new heights. â€œNicole's ability to convey raw emotion while commanding the stage is extraordinary,â€ says Sahaj Ticotin. â€œThese videos carve out her mark as a visionary artist.â€ â€œToxic,â€ a powerful dance pop anthem released via LA Music Records, delivers a raw, emotional narrative about overcoming toxic relationships, with captivating choreography and intense vocals that resonate deeply with audiences of all ages. â€œNicole is a rare talent who brings passion and precision to every performance,â€ says Alina Liwo, founder of ALITI Productions & Talent Agency, who has been instrumental in guiding Nicole's stage presence, singing, modeling, and acting. â€œHer dedication to her craft at such a young age is truly inspiring, and these new releases are a testament to her boundless potential. Despite her demanding schedule as a full-time student, Nicole commits over 15 hours weekly to honing her skills under the mentorship of Dubai's finest industry coaches. She trains in classical music and violin with Mariana Lutsiv and collaborates with internationally acclaimed music producer Robert M. to craft her signature sound. Nicole's dedication and drive are evident in every frame as well as her performances at the WATERBOMB 2024 Dubai Festival, where she debuted four original songs before 30,000 fans, and at elite venues like the Palazzo Versace Dubai, and Burj Khalifa's Armani Hotel, which have solidified her reputation. Nicole's star power extends beyond music, with appearances in renowned publications such as GLAMOUR, Wizaz, Polki.pl, and GOLDEN WINGS Luxury Magazine. Her poise, talent, and relentless work ethic have made her a sought-after figure in both the entertainment and fashion industries. Nicole's rise is backed by LA Music Records, and a team of industry veterans, including producer Robert M. and Grammy-winner RedOne. With her debut album slated for release in Q4 2025, featuring collaborations with both American and Emirati artists, these music videos signal Nicole's unstoppable ascent within the industry. Fans and media are invited to follow Nicole's journey as she continues to redefine what it means to be a young performer in today's global spotlight. The video, filmed across Dubai and Los Angeles at SoundStruck Studios and FIVE Hotel Music Studio, incorporates cutting-edge AI technology and futuristic visuals, elevating her artistry to new heights. â€œNicole's ability to convey raw emotion while commanding the stage is extraordinary,â€ says Sahaj Ticotin. â€œThese videos carve out her mark as a visionary artist.â€ â€œToxic,â€ a powerful dance pop anthem released via LA Music Records, delivers a raw, emotional narrative about overcoming toxic relationships, with captivating choreography and intense vocals that resonate deeply with audiences of all ages. â€œNicole is a rare talent who brings passion and precision to every performance,â€ says Alina Liwo, founder of ALITI Productions & Talent Agency, who has been instrumental in guiding Nicole's stage presence, singing, modeling, and acting. â€œHer dedication to her craft at such a young age is truly inspiring, and these new releases are a testament to her boundless potential. Despite her demanding schedule as a full-time student, Nicole commits over 15 hours weekly to honing her skills under the mentorship of Dubai's finest industry coaches. She trains in classical music and violin with Mariana Lutsiv and collaborates with internationally acclaimed music producer Robert M. to craft her signature sound. Nicole's dedication and drive are evident in every frame as well as her performances at the WATERBOMB 2024 Dubai Festival, where she debuted four original songs before 30,000 fans, and at elite venues like the Palazzo Versace Dubai, and Burj Khalifa's Armani Hotel, which have solidified her reputation. Nicole's star power extends beyond music, with appearances in renowned publications such as GLAMOUR, Wizaz, Polki.pl, and GOLDEN WINGS Luxury Magazine. Her poise, talent, and relentless work ethic have made her a sought-after figure in both the entertainment and fashion industries. Nicole's rise is backed by LA Music Records, and a team of industry veterans, including producer Robert M. and Grammy-winner RedOne. With her debut album slated for release in Q4 2025, featuring collaborations with both American and Emirati artists, these music videos signal Nicole's unstoppable ascent within the industry. Fans and media are invited to follow Nicole's journey as she continues to redefine what it means to be a young performer in today's global spotlight. â€‰ Nicole Obarzanek Redefines Dance - Pop Genres With Two Sensational New Music Video Releases - â€œInto Another Worldâ€ and â€œToxicâ€ Nicole Obarzanek Redefines Dance - Pop Genres With Two Sensational New Music Video Releases - â€œInto Another Worldâ€ and â€œToxicâ€ Nicole's ability to convey raw emotion while commanding the stage is extraordinaryâ€â€” Sahaj Ticotin, Los Angeles-based music producer LOS ANGELES, CA, UNITED STATES, July 8, 2025 /EINPresswire.com/ -- Nicole Obarzanek, the 14-year-old multi-talented prodigy from Dubai, is setting the global music scene ablaze with the release of two electrifying music videos for her singles â€œInto Another Worldâ€ and â€œToxic.â€ Born in Poland in 2010, and now a rising star in the UAE, Nicole's dynamic performances as a singer, dancer, actor, and model are showcased in these visually stunning videos, now streaming across YouTube, Apple Music, Spotify, and Anghami. â€œInto Another World,â€ produced by acclaimed Los Angeles-based producer Sahaj Ticotin, blends contemporary dance rhythms with orchestral elements, reflecting Nicole's rich musical heritage. The video, filmed across Dubai and Los Angeles at SoundStruck Studios and FIVE Hotel Music Studio, incorporates cutting-edge AI technology and futuristic visuals, elevating her artistry to new heights. â€œNicole's ability to convey raw emotion while commanding the stage is extraordinary,â€ says Sahaj Ticotin. â€œThese videos carve out her mark as a visionary artist.â€ â€œToxic,â€ a powerful dance pop anthem released via LA Music Records, delivers a raw, emotional narrative about overcoming toxic relationships, with captivating choreography and intense vocals that resonate deeply with audiences of all ages. â€œNicole is a rare talent who brings passion and precision to every performance,â€ says Alina Liwo, founder of ALITI Productions & Talent Agency, who has been instrumental in guiding Nicole's stage presence, singing, modeling, and acting. â€œHer dedication to her craft at such a young age is truly inspiring, and these new releases are a testament to her boundless potential. Despite her demanding schedule as a full-time student, Nicole commits over 15 hours weekly to honing her skills under the mentorship of Dubai's finest industry coaches. She trains in classical music and violin with Mariana Lutsiv and collaborates with internationally acclaimed music producer Robert M. to craft her signature sound. Nicole's dedication and drive are evident in every frame as well as her performances at the WATERBOMB 2024 Dubai Festival, where she debuted four original songs before 30,000 fans, and at elite venues like the Palazzo Versace Dubai, and Burj Khalifa's Armani Hotel, which have solidified her reputation. Nicole's star power extends beyond music, with appearances in renowned publications such as GLAMOUR, Wizaz, Polki.pl, and GOLDEN WINGS Luxury Magazine. Her poise, talent, and relentless work ethic have made her a sought-after figure in both the entertainment and fashion industries. Nicole's rise is backed by LA Music Records, and a team of industry veterans, including producer Robert M. and Grammy-winner RedOne. With her debut album slated for release in Q4 2025, featuring collaborations with both American and Emirati artists, these music videos signal Nicole's unstoppable ascent within the industry. Fans and media are invited to follow Nicole's journey as she continues to redefine what it means to be a young performer in today's global spotlight. Stay up on the latest music and news on Instagram (@nicole. obarzanek) and TikTok (@nicoleobarzanek. official). Nicole Obarzanek - Into Another World (Official Music Video)

â€‰ SPR_COMBO[it]Ãˆ l'8 luglio e in molti vedono avvicinarsi le ferie. Diciamoci la veritÃ , ci va poco di parlare della Paris Fashion Week (autunno/inverno, questo sconosciuto) e dei front row ai quali comunque non partecipiamo. La domanda fondamentale non Ã¨, stavolta, quella sulla vita l'universo e tutto quanto ma Ã¨ solo "cosa mettiamo in valigia?". Per gli ultimi giorni prima delle vacanze c'Ã¨ voglia di leggerezza, e chi dice leggerezza dice "guarderemo i look delle vip in location esotiche e capiremo se c'Ã¨ qualche spunto da copiare". Che Ã¨ proprio quello che faremo in questa ultima newsletter prima dell'estate vera e propria (sÃ¬, va in ferie anche la sottoscritta). Il bikini a fantasia (come Dua Lipa) Si aggira per i vicoli di Napoli con il futuro marito, si tuffa nelle acque cristalline delle Baleari insieme alle sue amiche e lo fa rigorosamente in costume a triangolo a fantasia. Il suo preferito - almeno a giudicare da Instagram - Ã¨ animalier, ma sfoggia volentieri anche un modello a pois (una delle fantasie dell'estate) con inserti di pizzo. Quello per la vacanza spagnola Ã¨ invece tempestato di cristalli. Il che la dice lunga sui modelli dell'estate: divertenti e dalle linee semplici. Il costume intero? Non pervenuto. Olivia Rodrigo e l'abitino gingham Non Ã¨ che staremoÂ sempre in spiaggia: certo, a questo punto potremmo non farcela per Wimbledon, ma un abitino bon ton in valigia puÃ² sempre servirci per un aperitivo o simili. Sceglietelo come il suo: a quadretti (in gergo gingham), altra fantasia estiva che a sorpresa ha invaso le boutique e tutti i guardaroba delle star, vedere anche alla voce Bella Hadid e Daisy Edgar Jones (il suo, bianco e nero, Ã¨ giÃ  sold out), che lo scelgono in versione prendisole. Il plus? Vi potete sbizzarrire sul colore.Â  Alexa Chung e la bandana Un occhio (anche alla comoditÃ ): avete presente quando, in spiaggia o durante un giro in barca, i capelli svolazzano e sembrate appena uscite dalla seduta di un parrucchiere pazzo? Fortunatamente Ã¨ tornata di gran moda la bandana, che risolverÃ  tutti i vostri problemi di bad hair day oltre a donarvi quel tocco glam necessario per le foto su Instagram. Come indossarla? Non come Axl Rose ma come vostra nonna. Letteralmente. Fidatevi.Â  Il parka come gli Oasis La maggior parte del genere umano non Ã¨ riuscita ad accaparrarsi un biglietto per la reunion dell'estate. Ma qualcuno andrÃ  in montagna: ed Ã¨ lÃ¬ che il mood "fratelli Gallagher" potrÃ  davvero sbizzarrirsi:Â secondo i dati raccolti Shopify il mese di giugno ha registrato un boom di ricerche per tutti i capi di abbigliamento che hanno reso iconici il duo inglese. Leggi parka, le felpe sportive (come le loro ironiche @adidas), bucket hat e giacche trucker.Â  PILLOLE FASHION L'ultima campagna di Donatella. A marzo Ã¨ arrivato il temuto annuncio: Donatella ha lasciato la guida creativa di Versace. Il colpo di teatro perÃ² era in agguato: per la campagna che segna il suo ultimo atto Donatella ha rispolverato i nomi che hanno reso grande la maison. Kate Moss, Claudia Schiffer, Amber Valletta fotografate daÂ Mert & Marcus per una collezione autunno-inverno dal fascino anni Novanta, che tanto ci piace.Â  La nuova era di Celine. Per ogni ultimo atto ce ne Ã¨ un primo: Ã¨ appena partita ufficialmente l'era di Michael Rider che subentra a Hedi Slimane come direttore creativo di Celine. La collezione, che Ã¨ stata giudicata positivamente da un po' tutti, non rivoluziona ma rielabora i codici della Maison, come si dice in gergo, mescolandoli con un po' di ironia.Â  Â© RIPRODUZIONE RISERVATA

â€‰ NEED TO KNOW Lily James revealed a shocking hair transformation while out in London Days before, the actress had been spotted with her usual honey blonde locks while at Glastonbury 2025 James has previously undergone dramatic hair transformations for photo shoots and acting roles Lily James is going to the dark side. On Saturday, July 5, the actress, 36, stepped out in London with a dramatic new look. In place of her usual honey blonde locks, James sported dark brunette hair that fades into a deep blue-black at the ends. The star was spotted on a casual stroll wearing navy leggings, a brown leather jacket and tan clogs. She carried a white canvas tote bag over her shoulder and wore little to no makeup. On Monday, July 7, James showed off her new look via . In a mirror selfie that appeared to be taken in a gym, the Baby Driver actress posed in a sports bra and leggings, her newly dark hair piled into a messy bun atop her head. Days before debuting her brunette transformation, James was seen with her usual lighter hair color at Glastonbury 2025. In an Instagram shared on June 29, the actress posed with actress Billie Piper at the festival. NASH / BACKGRID Lily James. The recent hair transformation is hardly James' first. In 2022, the actress donned a black wig with blunt bangs and bleached eyebrows in Versace's Fall/Winter 2022 campaign shot by famed duo Mert Alas and Marcus Piggott. Her ensemble in the campaign was also not lacking in drama; she wore a black corset with latex gloves while holding up the fashion house's new Greca Goddess bag. In another photo shared by the luxe Italian label's chief creative officer Donatella Versace onÂ , James is wearing a corseted red dress with red boots and a red bag. James famously underwent a dramatic transformation to play Pamela Anderson in the 2022 Hulu miniseriesÂ Pam & Tommy. In an interview with Variety, the show's hair department lead Barry Lee Moe revealed that the actress had to go through "anywhere from three to five hours of hair and makeupÂ every morning." â€‰ In today's Daily Rundown video, Chris Versace reviews the Portfolio's decision to lock in some gains on American Express  () Â shares on Monday morning, as well as why President Trump's August 1 tariff deadline has injected a fresh wave of uncertainty into the market. Chris also explains why the Portfolio will remain prudent but opportunistic as we head into the June quarter earnings season. And he discusses expectations for Amazon's  () Â 2025 Prime Day event, shares which companies we'll be listening to for confirmation, and why quarterly results from ConAgra  () Â could trigger some Bullpen work on our part. Transcript CHRIS VERSACE: Hey, everyone, Chris Versace. It is Monday, July 7. I hope you all had a fun, happy and safe Independence Day holiday. I know I certainly did, but here we are, kicking off the first full week of the September quarter. And as you probably saw, stocks are indeed trading off in response to renewed tariff and trade deal uncertainty. And you hopefully saw that we, in response to that, as well as the shares being overbought, took some profits in American Express shares early this morning. That decision to trim back and lock in some gains on Amex were a combination of the significant move in the shares since their April lows, but also the deep overbought. And by that, we mean relative strength index reading level that the shares had coming into this week. Stepping back a little bit when it comes to tariffs and trade deals, we're going to continue to see how the landscape develops. But our thinking is that if President Trump is coming out swinging, throwing out there this August 1 date when we could see tariff levels go back to their April 2 level, odds are there's some room for the market to be disappointed with what we're likely to hear in terms of announced trade deals in the next few days. Remember, today is the 7. The imposed trade deal deadline is July 9. We are hearing from certain White House officials that there will be deals announced in the next couple of days, but with the market overbought-- and by that, I mean the S&P 500 and the NASDAQ composite-- I'm kind of reading between the tea leaves. Trump throwing out this August 1 deadline seems to me to suggest that there could be some underwhelming interpretation of the deals that are announced. We've talked about this before, but it doesn't seem likely that we're going to get trade deals announced with Canada, with the Eurozone or China this week or anytime soon. So I suspect that's another reason why Trump is throwing out that August 1 date, as I talked about in our opening comments this morning, to try and reclaim the trade deal narrative. Now, again, we're going to continue to follow these developments. But make no mistake, we will remain prudent investors when and where it makes sense. Hence, our move this morning with American Express. But we will also look to remain opportunistic. So if you just think about some of the things that we did in the last few weeks, taking the pronounced strength in the shares of Microsoft, Marvell, NVIDIA, and even today with American Express, we've used them either to build up our cash positions, given what we see ahead or to make an opportunistic move, in some cases, the shares of Alphabet, SuRo Capital. And last week, we started a new position in the shares of TJX. Now, as we get ready for the June quarter earnings season, which is right around the corner, kicking up a gear arguably next week when we start to get big bank earnings, including those from Bank of America and Morgan Stanley, we're going to remain prudent and opportunistic investors. Now, some of the positions that we're interested in building up, TJX, obviously, it's our newest one, but also SuRo capital, ahead of what we expect to see the resumption of dividend payments given its BDC or business development company structure. But before we get to those big bank earnings, we do have a few things we want to talk about, especially Amazon's Prime Day event this week, as well as a number of competing ones. The usual cast of characters Walmart, Target, and a few others. Now remember, Amazon's Prime Day this year has been extended to four days from two, and it's going to run from Tuesday, July 7 through Friday, July 11. Now for context, Adobe Analytics sees the event hitting $23.8 billion across those four days. That's about a 28% or so increase year-over-year. Now, as we think about those numbers, do we have cost conscious consumers out there? We certainly do. Is there renewed tariff uncertainty, which could pull forward spending? Absolutely. And let's remember, too, that we also have before too long, even though the July 4th holiday has just passed, the back-to-school shopping season. So there are reasons to think that we could see some pull forward in spending happen. And based on what we see in terms of comments from other companies as they start reporting, whether it's Visa, Mastercard, or even our own American Express, we're likely to have some confirmation on the degree to which shoppers opened up their wallets during Prime Day and its competing events. Now, even though we sold some of American Express, it's that pull forward and spending, that strength in spending that we do want to capture with American Express shares, as well as the benefits of the upgrades that are coming to the platinum card membership. Remember, this is going to be the biggest that American Express has ever done. And typically, when we see that, we tend to see a nice kickup in terms of membership numbers. And we suspect that that will repeat. We also suspect that Amazon will be packing on the benefits to the platinum card in order to draw those members. It's that membership business model as to why we continue to favor American Express shares over the more transactional-led business models for Visa and Mastercard. Now, in addition to Prime Day and the competing events, which could be a catalyst for Amazon shares, we also have quarterly results starting this week with Conagra, Delta Airlines, and Levi Strauss. They're going to give us another dimension on consumer spending, especially I think what we hear from Conagra. Remember, they're predominantly packaged foods and frozen foods. To the extent that they see a pickup in volume, it would confirm some other signals that we're getting about consumers starting to eat increasingly at home, dialing back their restaurant spending....

â€‰ Lauren Sanchez stepped out in Paris for dinner with Brooks Nader on Tuesday She is still in Europe following a whirlwind wedding in Venice to Jeff Bezos Newlywed Lauren Sanchez looked red hot as she stepped out in Paris on Tuesday night to enjoy dinner with model Brooks Nader. SÃ¡nchez, who wed Amazon tycoon Jeff Bezos last month in a lavish, multi-day Venetian extravaganza, wore a latex dress by Versace, as she stepped out in the City of Lights. The formfitting bright red garment featured a corset bodice - that showcased her ample cleavage - as well as ruching at the skirt. It is currently retailing for $3,515 on luxury resale site Vestiaire Collective. The dress hit Lauren, 55, right above the knee and she paired the look with strappy black heels. It has also been worn by a few other celebrities this year, like model Amelia Gray Hamlin. The new Mrs. Bezos finished off the look with her hair sleek and straight, and carried a black crocodile HermÃ¨s Kelly bag, which typically has a resale value of over $50,000. Brooks Nader, 28, looked equally as glamorous for their Parisian night out, as she wore a pair of black capri pants and a totally sheer black halter blouse that left very little to the imagination. This week is theÂ Paris Haute Couture Week, which runs from July 7 to the 10. Lauren's husband, Jeff Bezos, is expected to attend Allen & Co.'s annual leadership retreat in Sun Valley this week. It appears to be the first sighting ofÂ SÃ¡nchez after her whirlwind nuptials, of which Brooks also attended. The luxe event, which not only featured their actual wedding but multiple themed parties and brunches, saw them surrounded by 200 friends and family. A-listers like Kim Kardashian, Ivanka Trump, and Kris Jenner all made an appearance, as well as Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates. Ellie Goulding performed at their reception, while Usher also sang at their pajama-themed brunch the next day. The happy couple got married in a restored amphitheater on the island, as SÃ¡nchez wore a high-neck, long sleeve lace Dolce & Gabbana gown that took over 900 hours of atelier to make, per Vogue. The gown featured a flared skirt, long veil, and a tight-fitting waist, with tons of buttons going up the middle. 'Very Lauren. Sexy, happy, not too serious, not too drama. Elegant but at the same time sensual,' Domenico Dolce told the outlet about the bride's dress. But the dress wasn't the only star of the show. The Blue Origin astronaut had many looks for the different occasions, including a pajama-themed party on their last night. SÃ¡nchez chose a strapless, dusty pink bustier Atelier Versace gown for the event, with bejeweled detailing all over the body - but it was her secret accessory that really stood out. Throughout the weekend, Lauren also wore many custom accessories that were a nod to her new last name, like a black rhinestone-encrusted black clutch bag that read, 'Mrs. Bezos' on it in silver gems. On the morning of her wedding, SÃ¡nchez stepped out in a cream, two-piece skirt suit by Dior, adding a personal touch as she wore a brown braided bracelet with diamond charms that read 'LB,' in honor of becoming Lauren Bezos. But for SÃ¡nchez, it's not about the dress or the accessories - at the end of the day, she's just happy to be married to Bezos, who she describes as the love of her life. 'I'm very happy,' she told the outlet. 'More than the dress, I'm happy that I'm getting married and I get to spend my life with my best friend, someone who sees me, someone who adores me, someone who I adore. I am the luckiest woman on the planet,' she shared.

â€‰ The only thing she's occupying now is the couch. Ilhan Omar's daughter, Isra Hirsi, is unemployed and hawking her used clothes online just months after graduating from the elite Barnard College, she announced in a Tuesday Instagram story. "Unemployment got me," Hirsi said, including a link to her page on Depop, a peer-to-peer marketplace. On the platform, Hirsi looked to unload some old clothing items, including a pair of Dr. Martens boots for $50 and her "beloved multicolored striped cardigan" for $15. Hirsi, like her mother, was an outspoken supporter of the pro-Hamas movement on campus during her time at Barnard. She is perhaps best known for being arrested at the Columbia University encampment in April 2024, which led to her suspension from Barnard. Barnard president Laura Rosenbury offered to lift the campus activists' suspensions less than a week later following after faculty issued public statements siding with encampment participants. Hirsi ultimately graduated from Barnard in May of this year, walking the stage with a Palestinian flag in hand, her Instagram page shows. It is unclear whether Hirsi's unemployment has any connection to her activities on campus, but a number of large employers, including ExxonMobil and the Sullivan & Cromwell law firm, stated at the time that they would not hire graduates who participated in pro-Hamas encampments. "Harassment and intimidation, I think there's no place for that at those universities and certainly no place for that at a company like ExxonMobil," CEO Darren Woods told CNBC last year. One thing Hirsi isn't selling yet is the pair of oversized Versace glasses she wears prominently in several photos, which retail for about $250.

Email tips@dailymail.com NewlywedÂ Lauren SanchezÂ looked sensational in a red skintight dress as she enjoyed a night out in Paris, France with some of her A-list friends on Tuesday. It marks Sanchez's first public outing since she and Amazon tycoon Jeff Bezos,Â 61, tied the knot during their lavish $50million Italian wedding weekend last month. Sanchez and Bezos hostedÂ 200 elite guests during the controversial three-day extravaganza â€” which many dubbed the 'Wedding of the Century.' The celebration continued this past weekend as the couple spent their 'honeymoon' partying on a yacht with recently split couple, Katy Perry and Orlando Bloom, in Capri. And on Tuesday night, a solo Sanchez ventured to Paris without her billionaire husband where she met up with Oscar-winners LeonardoÂ DiCaprio, Sean Penn and model Brooks NaderÂ and more stars for an upscale dinnerÂ at Laperouse restaurant. The new Mrs. Bezos, 55, made jaws drop upon arrival as she flashed her ample cleavage in a red latex dress byÂ Versace, which retails for over $3,500. She finished off the look with her hair sleek and straight, and carried a black crocodile HermÃ¨s Kelly bag, which typically has a resale value of over $50,000. Sanchez was photographed exitingÂ Laperouse, which is situated along the Seine and boasts private dining rooms, with a crew of security guards surrounding her. She smiled while being escorted to a nearby SUV as locals and paparazzi looked on in awe. Sanchez's model pal Nader put on anÂ X-rated display for their night out in Paris by goingÂ braless under a black see-through pussy bow blouse. The shocking top left nothing to the imagination as Nader, 28, confidently exitedÂ Laperouse with a security guard in tow. The blonde bombshell completed her racy outfit with skintight capri pants, sky-high heels and a shiny black clutch. As for her glam, Nader's plump pout was drenched in lip gloss and her long hair looked extra voluminous for the invite-only occasion amid Paris Fashion Week. Nader's younger sister Sarah Jane Nader was also in attendance. The brunette beauty was pictured walking behind her model sister in a daringly low-cut top. DiCaprio â€” who was recently branded a 'hypocrite' for associating with Bezos â€”Â tried to keep a low-profile as he left the restaurant before Sanchez and Nader. Dressed in a casual all-black outfit, the 50-year-old famous face was barely visible behind an N95 and a black baseball cap, which he pulled down to cover his eyes. The look resembled viral photos from the Bezos-Sanchez wedding that showed a tuxedo-clad DiCaprio seemingly trying to 'hide' from cameras byÂ wearing a hat low down over his eyes and nose. Missing from DiCaprio's side on Tuesday night was hisÂ supermodel girlfriend Vittoria Ceretti, 27. Instead, DiCaprio was joined by a single bodyguard as he made a beeline to a nearby chauffeured car parked outside ofÂ Laperouse. Penn, 64, rolled up the A-list gathering with his stunning 30-year-old girlfriend, Valeria Nicov. The Mystic River star looked slimmer than ever in a trendy neutral-toned outfit asÂ Nicov, wearing a white blouse and black slacks, trailed behind him. The couple, who made their red carpet debut last December, were photographed walking into the restaurant separately. SocialiteÂ Natasha Poonawalla was also on hand for Sanchez's star-studded dinner in Paris. Bezos' absence from the dinner party was likely due to a scheduling conflict as he is expected to attendÂ Allen & Co.'s annual leadership retreat in Sun Valley, Idaho this week. Days before Sanchez's Paris trip, the journalist and Bezos were spotted partying on a superyacht in the Mediterranean during what many believed was their honeymoon. The couple was joined by Katy Perry, Katy's ex-fiance Orlando Bloom and other friends as they soaked up in the sun over the weekend. However, DailyMail.com recently learned that the trip was technically not an official honeymoon for Bezos and Sanchez, who appeared to be enjoying their extended vacation following their Venice nuptials. The luxe three-day event, which not only featured their actual wedding but multiple themed parties and brunches, saw the couple surrounded by 200 friends and family. A-listers like Kim Kardashian, Ivanka Trump, and Kris Jenner all made an appearance, as well as Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates. Ellie Goulding performed at their reception, while Usher also sang at their pajama-themed brunch the next day. The happy couple got married in a restored amphitheater on the island, as SÃ¡nchez wore a high-neck, long sleeve lace Dolce & Gabbana gown that took over 900 hours of atelier to make, per Vogue. The gown featured a flared skirt, long veil, and a tight-fitting waist, with tons of buttons going up the middle. 'Very Lauren. Sexy, happy, not too serious, not too drama. Elegant but at the same time sensual,' Domenico Dolce told the outlet about the bride's dress. But the dress wasn't the only star of the show. The Blue Origin astronaut had many looks for the different occasions, including a pajama-themed party on their last night. Sanchez chose a strapless, dusty pink bustier Atelier Versace gown for the event, with bejeweled detailing all over the body - but it was her secret accessory that really stood out. Throughout the weekend, Lauren also wore many custom accessories that were a nod to her new last name, like a black rhinestone-encrusted black clutch bag that read, 'Mrs. Bezos' on it in silver gems. On the morning of her wedding, Sanchez stepped out in a cream, two-piece skirt suit by Dior, adding a personal touch as she wore a brown braided bracelet with diamond charms that read 'LB,' in honor of becoming Lauren Bezos. But for Sanchez, it's not about the dress or the accessories - at the end of the day, she's just happy to be married to Bezos, who she describes as the love of her life. 'I'm very happy,' she told the outlet. 'More than the dress, I'm happy that I'm getting married and I get to spend my life with my best friend, someone who sees me, someone who adores me, someone who I adore. I am the luckiest woman on the planet,' she shared.

â€‰ Amazon founder Jeff Bezos was nowhere to be seen as Lauren Sanchez enjoyed a lavish dinner with her famous pals in Paris this week Newlyweds Jeff Bezos and Lauren Sanchez have been celebrating their honeymoon after tying the knot in a Â£48million wedding in Venice last month. Where most people usually spend their honeymoon enjoying a romantic break, the Amazon founder and his new bride opted to invite their famous pals to join them on the celebrations. Over the weekend, Katy Perry and Orlando Bloom were spotted with newlyweds Jeff Bezos and Lauren Sanchez on what appeared to be part of the couple's honeymoon. Katy and Orlando, who said they are now focusing on co-parenting their daughter Daisy Dove, hopped on board Bezos' superyacht in the Mediterranean with their little girl. A few days later, Lauren jetted off to Paris without her new husband to enjoy a night out with a host of A-list friends, including Leonardo DiCaprio, Sean Penn and Brooks Nader. The famous pals were pictured leaving Laperouse restaurant after a lavish dinner. Lauren, 55, looked out of this world in a red latex dress from Versace. She completed the look with a black Hermes handbag and black sunglasses as she made her way out. Brooks went all out in capris, a mesh halterneck top with bow detailing and a black purse. Brooks' younger sister, Sarah Jane Nader, also joined in on the night. Sean and Leonardo, on the other hand, opted for casual looks as they walked out in baggy trousers, simple T-shirts and light jackets. Leonardo kept hidden in a black face mask with a cap pushed down over his face. Last month, Jeff and Lauren tied the knot in Venice despite threats and protests by anti-capitalists and locals. The 25-minute wedding ceremony saw the pair exchange vows in front of around 200 guests, including a number of high-profile celebrities. In attendance were the Kardashian-Jenners, Orlando Bloom and Oprah Winfrey, as well as Ivanka Trump and her family. Rania Al Abdullah, the Queen of Jordan also watched on, as did supermodels, actors and business-people. Guests were welcomed by a gospel choir, with the singers performing a rendition of Whitney Houston's Higher Love as the bride and groom entered. Most guests partied well into the early hours of Saturday, but some celebs slipped away early. Kim and Khloe Kardashian left the do early and had already left the country by the time some of the other guests woke up, having being spotted at Venice airport early in the morning. Jeff kept his party gifts fancy, giving his male guests ViBi Venezia blue velvet slippers. But Sanchez partook in some shameless marketing, handing out black open-toe slippers from Amazon, promoting the business empire that made her now-husband a billionaire. According to a well-placed insider involved in the event planning, it's said the couple were already legally married for at least a month before the wedding. They said: â€œThey have been married for at least a month, more than a month. The marriage is fully legal and took place in America under American law.â€ Follow Mirror Celebs on TikTok, Snapchat, Instagram, Twitter,

The Vera Wang Princess Eau de Toilette 30ml is one of the most sought-after fragrances on the online giant's platform - now reduced from Â£42 to Â£11.97. Prime members can access the vast majority of the exclusive deals and while a membership costs around Â£8.99 per month, Amazon is letting shoppers try it free for 30 days. It gets users benefits like unlimited one-day and same-day delivery, Prime Videos, ad-free Prime Music and more. The Vera Wang Princess Eau de Toilette is Amazon's number one best-seller in the perfume category and with an overwhelming 54,550 global ratings, the fragrance boasts an exquisite blend with top notes of apple and water lily, a heart featuring pink guava and dark chocolate, and a sumptuous base of amber and vanilla. The lovely heart-shaped bottle also features a regal-looking golden bottle cap with amethyst-coloured crystals. Shoppers can also get the same perfume at Boots, which is currently sellingÂ  a 100ml bottle for Â£26,where it's available for next-day delivery with code FREENEXTDAY. Meanwhile, Charlotte Tilbury is offering its "mood-boosting" Love Frequency Perfume Set for Â£91 instead of Â£130 - a saving of 30%. Shoppers can get their hands on the brand's woody floral fragrance in both 100ml and 10ml bottles. The light and floral scent has been described as "perfect for daytime" while some loyal fans have called it their "all time favourite", reports Liverpool Echo. One shopper noted: "What sets Vera Wang Princess apart is its versatility. It seamlessly transitions from day to night, making it suitable for various occasions. Whether you're attending a casual outing or a formal event, this fragrance complements any ensemble and leaves a trail of elegance and charm in your wake." A delighted customer shared their experience: "My wife loves this. It smells beautiful, not too strong but the smell lingers for hours/days. A very sweet floral smell, I guarantee everyone will compliment." Another shopper wrote: "Bought this multiple times as my partner can't get enough of it over more expensive perfumes I've bought her. The bottle size is also great." A third customer expressed their newfound adoration for the fragrance, stating: "First time trying this perfume and I love it that much that I bought another one, got big size bottles and well worth it. It's my new favourite scent." Yet, not all feedback was glowing; one customer lamented the perfume's longevity: "Beautiful scent but doesn't last at all, I have to add more on several times during the day. Smells lovely and fresh though." Another shopper was left wanting more from the fragrance's intensity: "Its a nice perfume but the smell is a bit faint, it's a bit too subtle and doesn't last very long. Really need to sniff to figure out the notes." But a satisfied shopper enthused: "It's versatile for any occasion and leaves a lasting impression. A true masterpiece." For those interested in purchasing, Vera Wang's Princess Eau De Toilette is on sale at Amazon. In other deals, LookFantastic is offering a 50% discount on Versace's Woman Eau de Parfum 50ml, now Â£33 down from Â£66. Additionally, Boots has launched a significant fragrance sale, with some perfumes reduced to half price. READ NEXT

â€‰ Richmond outlet mall has welcomed brands such as Under Armour, Zwilling and Karl Lagerfeld for their first stores in the region Ten years after its launch on July 9, 2015, the McArthurGlen Outlet Vancouver Airport is bustling with shoppers, and its executives sayÂ they plan to expand the region's only outlet centre. It is a testament that retail success can come when developers target a clear niche and there is unmet demand in the market. â€œWe're working through permitting and some leasing right now, and we'll have an opening date announcement of Phase 3 in the next couple of months,â€ said Robert Thurlow, general manager of what is largely a mall with tenants that sell off-price merchandise. His expected 63,000-square-foot expansion would enlarge the Richmond mall to approximately 387,000 square feet ofÂ leasable space. AnÂ expansion has been in the works for years. The mall was a success from day one. Mall executives back thenÂ counted about 160,000 shoppers in the mall's first four days, and traffic jams on roads leading to the complex disrupted vehicle flow for those heading to the nearby Vancouver International Airport. Months later itÂ won an award for being the world's best outlet centre. The mall initially had about 240,000 square feet ofÂ leasableÂ space,Â of which 156,000 square feet was leased on opening day. Within three years, the mall had filled about 96 per cent of that space with tenants,Â ThurlowÂ toldÂ BIV. An 84,000-square-foot Phase 2 expansion opened toward the southeast in 2019, and Thurlow said Phase 3 is set to add another 63,000 square feet to the northeast of the original mall footprint. FuelingÂ the expansion is retail success. Thurlow pinned the mall retailers' average annual sales per square foot at about $1,350. The mall does not take part in the International Council of ShoppingÂ Centers' (ICSC) annual ranking of Canadian shopping centres by that metric. If it had done so, it would have last year ranked No. 5 in Canada, and No. 3 in B.C., behind CF Pacific Centre's $1,454 per square foot, and CF Richmond Centre's $1,359 per square foot on theÂ ICSCÂ rankings. â€œMcArthurGlenÂ is an extremely well-performing shopping centre,â€ Retail Insider owner and consultant Craig Patterson toldÂ BIV. â€œIt's got a value proposition to it. It's a mall that has stores that are known to have lower prices, and it has got a compelling mix of brands. People will line up for certain brands that are on sale, andÂ McArthurGlenÂ has a good number of those brands.â€ The mall's largest retail tenant is Ralph Lauren, which leases about 20,000 square feet, according toÂ Thurlow. That location is Ralph Lauren's first outlet location in Metro Vancouver, he said. The clothing chain has had other full-price stores in the region but never a store that carried off-price merchandise such as out-of-season clothing or products specifically made for an outlet store, according toÂ Thurlow. Brands that opened their first-ever store in the region â€“ full price or outlet â€“ at the McArthurGlen Outlet Vancouver Airport mall include Under Armour, Zwilling and Karl Lagerfeld,Â ThurlowÂ said. The first Marc Jacobs outlet store in Western Canada opened at the mall earlier this year, he added. His mall caters to a wide range of tastes and price ranges, withÂ VersaceÂ being a luxury store that has its only store in Metro Vancouver at the mall. To mark the 10thÂ anniversary, the mall has encouraged tenants to offer special discounts. Mall management has also arranged for live music, special events and contests with prizes, such as a round-tripÂ HelijetÂ excursion to Victoria to stay two nights at theÂ FairmontÂ Empress hotel. â€‰ Just weeks after donning a high-neck, long-sleeved lace gown for her wedding to Amazon founder Jeff Bezos, has made her first public appearance as a newlywedâ€”quickly returning to her old fashion habits. The 55-year-old stepped out in Paris on Tuesday night for dinner with model wearing a skintight, fire-red dress by Versace that, for many, looked more clubwear than couture. Netizens, as usual, were ruthless in their commentary, with many wondering whether she could breathe as the corset-style bodice tightly pushed her cleavage up. â€œThat dress is so tight her fake boobs are ,â€ one commenter mocked. Another sniped, â€œWas that her wedding present, bigger balloons? Lauren Sanchez got roasted by the internet for stepping out in skin-tight bodysuit that compressed her chest The $3,515 dress, currently listed on luxury resale site Vestiaire Collective, clung to her frame and hit just above the knees, putting her legs on full display alongside strappy black heels and a $50,000 HermÃ¨s Kelly bag. For many viewers, the contrast between her face and her knees was striking, serving as a reminder that while cosmetic procedures can smooth a face, they don't extend to the legs. â€œThe knees show it all,â€ one user wrote. â€œThere is nothing real about this woman except being a home wrecker and gold digger.â€ Ever since she attended Donald Trump's inauguration wearing a revealing white blazer that brought plenty of attention to her chest, Sanchez Bezos has been at the center of ongoing scrutiny. Her cleavage at the event was so prominent it became a meme in itselfâ€”circulating widely alongside photos of a visibly distracted Mark Zuckerberg, who appeared unable to look away. â€œShe better watch or she will puncture one of her implants, stuffing it into these getups,â€ one user wrote. Her image took another hit earlier this year with the fallout from Blue Origin's all-female spaceflight, a mission she led alongside pop star Katy Perry and four other women. Though touted by the Bezos-owned aerospace company as a historic achievementâ€”marking the first all-female flight beyond the KÃ¡rmÃ¡n line since 1963â€”the launch was quickly dismissed by many as a tone-deaf vanity project. Sanchez' marriage to Bezos is her third, with their relationship starting while both were engaged to their respective previous partners @purepeople âœ¨ Lauren Sanchez et Brooks Nader ont Ã©tÃ© aperÃ§ues ce soir Ã  Paris, se rendant ensemble Ã  un dÃ®ner dans la capitale, en marge de la Fashion Week Haute Couture. Complices et ultra stylÃ©es, les deux amies ont attirÃ© tous les regards avec leurs looks glamour, entre Ã©lÃ©gance et vibes parisiennes. Une apparition remarquÃ©e sous les flashs dans les rues de la Ville LumiÃ¨re. #LaurenSanchez #BrooksNader #ParisNights #HauteCouture #FashionWeek #BestImage #purepeople â™¬ son original â€“ Purepeople The dinner, part of Paris Haute Couture Week, was also attended by Brooks Nader who wore capri pants and a sheer black halter blouse. While both women turned heads in the French capital, it was Sanchez Bezos that captured the attention of netizens. â€œShe looks very uncomfortable,â€ another netizen wrote. â€œNot sure how she even breathed in the dress.â€ Her appearance comes fresh off the heels of her opulent Venetian wedding to Bezos, which featured a restored amphitheater ceremony, a Dolce & Gabbana gown that allegedly took over 900 hours to make, and performances by Ellie Goulding and Usher. The high-profile guest list included Kim Kardashian, Kris Jenner, Ivanka Trump, and Bill Gates. Lauren Sanchez Bezos' marriage to Jeff Bezos is her third. Her first husband was former NFL tight end Tony Gonzalez, with whom she shares a son, Nikko, born in 2001. Her second marriage, far more high-profile, was to Patrick Whitesell, a powerful Hollywood agent and the executive chairman of Endeavor. They married in 2005 and had two children together. Sanchez and Bezos began their relationship while she was still married to Whitesell and he was still married to MacKenzie Scott. The affair, which was exposed via leaked text messages in 2019, ended both marriages and set off one of the most expensive divorces in history. Sanchez declared herself happy, and said that Bezos is not only a husband to her, but her best friend @taoualitamar #laurensanchez wife of #jeffbezos in #paris â™¬ son original â€“ AMAR TAOUALIT For Sanchez Bezos, the social media noise seems irrelevant. â€œI'm very happy,â€ she told the press after the wedding. â€œMore than the dress, I'm happy that I'm getting married and I get to spend my life with my best friend, someone who sees me, someone who adores me, someone who I adore. I am the luckiest woman on the planet.â€ While many defended her and accused her detractors of being jealous of her success, even her fans believe her love life has been more strategic than passionate. â€œYou don't bag three top-5% men in one lifetime without being a bit strategic, transactional, and calculated about your love life,â€ a user wrote. Among her fanbase, the 55-year-old is praised for maintaining an alluring image and refusing to conform to what's expected of her considering her age and status. â€œShe is extremely fit, well-groomed, and stylish in a seductive way while most other women her age tend to ditch that kind of 'bombshell' sex appeal for a more classy 'wifey material' look,â€ a fan stated. â€œNo class!â€ Netizens took to social media to criticize Sanchez Bezos for her dress

Done. Uni and a part-time job? Balanced. But then life did what it does best â€” humbled me Because no one warns you about the invisible costs. The kind that sneak up on you on a random Tuesday. The  kind that don't show up on your budget spreadsheet but always seem to show up in real life. Like you step out for â€œjust eggs and milkâ€ and come back Â£30 poorer. Or your laundry card suddenly needs another Â£10 and you're down to your last pair of socks. Or your train to London is Â£40 one way because you booked 3 days late. It's not even about being reckless. It's justâ€¦ life here is expensive in ways that are hard to plan for. Especially when you're new, learning the system, figuring things out, and trying to keep it all together on a student budget. And the truth is Living here is not just rent + groceries + WiFi It's also: â€” Bus passes, Uber when it rains (which is always) â€” Indian groceries and takeaways when you're too tired to cook â€” Bedding, toilet rolls, painkillers, scissors, socks, water filters â€” Spontaneous society events, someone's birthday, â€” Emotional support coffee â˜• That's why I'm saying this: An emergency fund isn't a rich people thing. It's a survival buffer. You don't need to save Â£1,000 overnight. Start with Â£5 a week. Or whatever you can. It's for that one week where everything goes wrong. And trust me â€” there will be a week like that. Save this post. It'll make sense later. â€‰ First impressions: 1. Groove is still in the heart. Dee-lite's Lady Miss Kir dressed as Cher from Clueless. 2A. Bad case of "these are the designers I'm wearing"--I GOT MUSTARD ON MY VERSACE! DID YOU HEAR ME? MY VERSACE! MUSTARD ON IT! 2B. Spotted wearing giant Chanel logo on chain in next episode promos 2C. Don't touch the "emotional support Birkin"--bitch bring a dog like everyone else. 3. Entire interview dedicated to letting us know she wasn't a gold digger, then presents photo showing younger self coyly seated atop rich old man's lap. OK toots. Just own it. That pic wasn't taken on his break from his janitor shift, it was taken on his private plane. SOMETHING made him attractive... 4. Seems hard working, I like that. 5. Has inserted finger into a chicken, always a handy bon mot to bring up at a baby shower. Props. Martina once again is dragged off to some party where she gamely pretends to support her wife in all her endeavors, including appreciating Kiki twerking in her face and examining the contents of a diaper. Guerdy is filmed crying to Russell about having water thrown at her as though she were the Wicked Witch. In fact, she does highly resemble Elphaba and this could be her ticket to Broadway and being Very Rich, Bitch like Nene's former glory days. Put a pin in that one. Russell expresses concern that Julia, a quote "very large, tall woman" was STANDING OVER his beloved while she is still recovering from breast cancer (no statute of limitations on that one I guess). Umm, has he ever seen Guerdy stand up? Aren't they all rather tall other than Marysol and maybe Lisa and Adriana? Speaking of Lisa--praise be to the editors for that magical juxtaposition of Jody and the Furby. I laughed so hard I startled my dog. Marysol has been suspiciously sober this season so far. I'm glad for her, but sad for myself. I wonder if it will last. Larsa stages a phone call with a [s]witness[/s] friend for backup regarding her story about Jody's suspiciously amped behavior at the "fashion" show they attended. Was this a no-phones-allowed event? She could have just recorded him and shown us all, but I guess maybe that's discouraged by the editors, IDK. Alexia --I cannot muster up even one giveadamn about her marriage to whatever his name was. If this was the best storyline she could come up with, her days as a HW are numbered.

â€‰ Numerator's research on the first two days of the event found that 30 percent of shoppers are clicking on apparel or footwear, tying with household essentials. Amazon's mini Christmas in July has consumers clicking on fashion â€” and there are more apparel brands in the promotional mix, including vintage designer style from ReBag as well as looks from Michael Kors, Naadam and more. Prime Day, which extended to four days this year and ends on Friday, has become a fixture on the retail calendar, prompting competing deals from other retailers. Altogether, retailers are expected to see $23.8 billion in sales, or the equivalent of two Black Fridays, according to Adobe. At Amazon, the event has had a strong fashion start. Numerator is tracking the e-commerce giant's Prime Day take, studying the activity of shoppers at 22,411 households and surveying 2,248 buyers during the sale's first two days. Thirty percent of buyers snatched up Prime Day apparel and footwear â€” tying for the top spot with cleaning products and other household essentials, according to the data and tech company. But in keeping with the general sense of caution in the market, consumers are being very calculated as they spend. Fifty-one percent of shoppers bought items that they'd been waiting to buy on sale and 37 percent of shoppers bought the same items they typically buy on Amazon. Numerator pegged the average order size on Prime Day at $57.12 and said 51 percent of households have made two or more orders, upping the average household spend to $126.26. Two-thirds of the Prime Day items have sold for under $20 while only 3 percent are over $100. Amazon has been steadily adding to its fashion mix and a company spokesperson pointed to the slate of fashions making their Prime Day debut. For the first time, the luxury resale player Rebag is offering price promotions on looks from Alexander McQueen, ChloÃ©, Delvaux, Givenchy, Jacquemus, Valentino Garavani, Versace and Tom Ford on Amazon. And a host of brands have joined the rush this year and included select items in the event, such as HervÃ© LÃ©ger, Kate Barton, Calzedonia, Vans, Michael Kors and Naadam.
