â€‰ Newlywed Lauren SÃ¡nchez-Bezos has made her first public appearance since her lavish Venetian wedding to Amazon founder Jeff Bezos, and she did so in unforgettable style. Stepping out in Paris for dinner with model Brooks Nader and her sister, Sarah Jane Nader, SÃ¡nchez stunned in a striking red latex dress by Versace. The eye-catching gown, retailing for around Â£2,700 ($3,515), featured a corset bodice that accentuated her curves, a ruched skirt, and a hemline just above the knee. Paired with strappy black heels and her signature confidence, the look turned heads across the City of Light. The dinner took place at the luxurious Laperouse restaurant after SÃ¡nchez was seen leaving the historic HÃ´tel de Crillon. Paris served as the perfect backdrop for her glamorous return, especially with the city buzzing for Haute Couture Week, running from 7 to 10 July. The evening marked SÃ¡nchez's first public sighting since her whirlwind wedding celebrations in Venice just last month. She and Bezos tied the knot in a multi-day extravaganza attended by 200 close friends and family. The guest list was star-studded, featuring Kim Kardashian, Ivanka Trump, Kris Jenner, and Bill Gates. Ellie Goulding performed at the reception, and Usher entertained guests at a playful pyjama-themed brunch the following day. For the ceremony, SÃ¡nchez wore a breathtaking Dolce & Gabbana lace gown inspired by screen legend Sophia Loren. The gown, featuring a high neck, long sleeves, and a sweeping veil, reportedly took over 900 hours to create in the atelier. She complemented it with a flared skirt and an intricately buttoned waist, embodying timeless elegance and cinematic glamour. During other events across the multi-day celebration, she showcased her bold sense of style: a gold corseted Schiaparelli couture dress at the welcome dinner and a rose-pink atelier Versace gown adorned with Swarovski crystals at their 'Dolce Notte' party. Each look highlighted her confident and sensual aesthetic, perfectly balancing drama and sophistication. Her return to Paris carries special meaning. The city hosted her unforgettable bachelorette festivities, where she celebrated with friends in a series of sheer and lacy looks that foreshadowed her bridal style. The recent red Versace ensemble echoed this playful spirit, capturing her fearless approach to fashion while marking a new chapter as a newlywed. The ensemble was completed with a black crocodile HermÃ¨s Kelly bag â€” estimated to be worth over Â£39,000 ($50,000) â€” and her hair worn sleek and straight for a polished finish. While SÃ¡nchez enjoyed her stylish evening in Paris, Bezos was expected to attend Allen & Co.'s annual leadership retreat in Sun Valley, a private gathering known for attracting influential figures from the worlds of tech and business. Lauren SÃ¡nchez Bezos has shown that her post-wedding glow extends far beyond romance, radiating through her bold fashion choices and undeniable confidence. Her striking Paris appearance blends glamour, sophistication, and a hint of nostalgia â€” a true celebration of love, style, and self-expression.

â€‰ Article created by: Gabija Saveiskyte  These boots were made for walking, and those gloves were made for grabbing all the lemons life may throw at you at any given time. Lamps, paintings, handbags, and much more that we humans are capable of creating with just a little bit of inspiration and a whole lot of sweat-inducing work. Regardless of the outcome, handmade goods are always to be celebrated. They're unique, and mayhaps sometimes imperfect, but that's all the more reason to be proud of what you've made. And today, to give you some inspiration and induce an 'awe' or two, we'll be looking at the most recent posts from the r/somethingimade subreddit. We reached out to the moderators of the page and one of them, named u/mtj510, was kind enough to answer a few of our questions, so make sure you stick around for that! Make sure to upvote your favorites as you're scrolling through, leave some comments along the way and tell us the most creative thing you've ever made, maybe even share linksâ€”we're curious, alright! And if you're craving a little more, Bored Panda has you covered with an article right here . Now let's get into it! On a date night with husband Adam Shulman in New York City, Hathaway carried a $120 JW Pei Maze bagâ€”and thanks to Amazon Prime Day, you can snag the exact same one for just $96. Courtesy of brand JW Pei Maze Crossbody $120 $96 (20% off) Amazon Hathaway's choice isn't too surprising when you consider JW Pei's dedicated celebrity following. Selena Gomez wore another of the brand's bags (also 20% off for Prime Day) to the 2024 Golden Globes alongside a couture gown. Gigi Hadid, Emily Ratajkowksi, and Hailey Bieber have also been spotted in the label, which is readily available on Amazon. In case you're not familiar, Prime Day is Amazon's biggest sale of the year, and it's double the usual length for 2025: The deals kicked off on July 8 and continue through Friday, July 11. Like many of the best markdownsâ€”including another on one of Katie Holmes's go-to bagsâ€”you can only access JW Pei's sale prices with an Amazon Prime membership. (Sign up here.) â€‰ She paired the metallic heels with a beaded Loewe dress. Vanessa Kirby stepped into shine and structure for Thursday's London premiere of â€œThe Fantastic Four: First Steps,â€ wearing Aquazzura's Minute Sandal 105 in metallic silver â€” the latest entry in her sculptural maternity footwear streak.QUES The Italian-made stilettos featured mirrored leather uppers, two slim straps and a high, tapered heel. A back zip created a clean finish at the ankle, and the brand's signature gold plaque was visible on the sole. The 105mm silhouette added lift without disrupting the overall proportion. Related Stories Kirby paired the sandals with a beaded turquoise dress from Loewe's spring 2025 collection. The strapless midi-length look, styled by Andrew Mukamal, was constructed entirely of layered bead strands that created fringe-like movement across the body. The runway version featured a shorter hemline and metallic underlayer, but Kirby's custom iteration removed any lining to emphasize the vertical drape. Combined with the clean stiletto, the full look felt visually elongated. This marked Kirby's latest footwear-forward look on the â€œFantastic Four: First Stepsâ€ press tour. Earlier this week in Paris, she wore metallic wraparound stilettos with a lilac Givenchy halter dress. In Mexico, she styled two different Manolo Blahnik silhouettes â€” including the black snakeskin Paloma heel â€” with cutout knits and a teal Schiaparelli gown. And at the Alabama trailer launch in February, she wore pointed PVC stilettos with vintage Versace. Across each appearance, Kirby has relied on heels with clean lines and exaggerated finishes â€” think eye-catching metallics, sheer panels and snakeskin â€” to ground dresses that range from architectural to body-conscious. â€œThe Fantastic Four: First Stepsâ€ marks the Marvel franchise's official reboot under Disney, introducing a new cast led by Kirby, Pedro Pascal, Joseph Quinn and Ebon Moss-Bachrach. Directed by Matt Shakman, the film serves as both an origin story and launchpad for the characters' integration into the broader MCU, ahead of their expected crossover appearances in â€œAvengers: Secret Wars.â€ The film opens in U.S. theaters on July 25. â€‰ Explore the global luxury apparel market to 2029 with insights into key trends, sales, and growth projections across regions. The market faced a 2.4% contraction in 2024 due to economic challenges, yet clothing is set for a 3.1% CAGR boost. Discover how top brands like Louis Vuitton and HermÃ¨s navigate the landscape. Dublin, July 11, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- The "Luxury Apparel Market to 2029" report has been added to ResearchAndMarkets.com's offering. This report offers an analysis of both the historic and forecast data of the global luxury apparel market through to 2029. It provides a insights into key trends within the luxury apparel market, alongside sales and growth across different regions and category groups. It also highlights key global luxury apparel brands and their current competitive position. The luxury apparel market is expected to have contracted 2.4% in 2024, due to macroeconomic challenges such as inflation in Europe and the US and the downturn in China affecting consumer spending. Between 2024 and 2029, clothing is projected to achieve the strongest category CAGR of 3.1%, driven by ultra-wealthy shoppers prioritizing trend-driven purchases, with womenswear expected to outperform. Asia-Pacific is set to achieve the strongest regional 2024-2029 CAGR of 4.0%, fueled by the recovery of China, along with strong economic growth in emerging markets. Louis Vuitton remains by far the largest luxury apparel brand, slightly gaining share to 9.8% in 2024. Hermes is was the biggest winner in 2024, with its share rising 0.7ppts to 6.0%, thanks to its exclusivity and superior quality retaining ultra-wealthy luxury shoppers. Scope The luxury market will slightly outperform the total apparel market from 2028 onwards as macroeconomic conditions improve The Asia-Pacific region will continue to grow share, thanks to its fast-growing income levels Footwear will continue to underperform out to 2029, as consumers favour trainers from premium and mass market brands Reasons to Buy Gain an understanding of the drivers and inhibitors in the global luxury apparel market Understand where the demand lies within the global luxury apparel market across categories, and brands, to allow you to maximise customer acquisition. Identify the key approaches brands are taking to stand out in the global luxury apparel market, and how you can adapt these to fit your own business. â€‰ It's a brand the Princess of Wales had enjoyed earlier in her royal life. Rachel Burchfield is the contributing royals editor at InStyle, where she covers news about the British royal family on a daily basis, including the work and wardrobes of Kate Middleton and Meghan Markle. Close Princess Diana on June 17, 1997. Credit: Getty Though Princess Diana wore Chanel tweed suits earlier in her royal life, in her later yearsâ€”and especially after her 1996 divorceâ€”she found it difficult to wear Chanel for the most heartbreaking reason. The brand's interlocked Cs iconic logo reminded her too much of Prince Charles and Camilla Parker Bowlesâ€”whose affair dominated much of Diana's 15-year marriage to Charles. As Diana herself said in a 1995 interview, there were three people in her marriage, so it was a bit crowded. In the final years of her life, Princess Diana was a fan of many designer labelsâ€”think Versace and Dior, for startersâ€”but one fashion house she avoided? Chanelâ€”and for the most heartbreaking reason. It's not because she wasn't a fan of their clothesâ€”it boiled down to her husband Prince Charles's longstanding affair with Camilla Parker Bowles, an affair that had plagued much of their marriage. Chanel, of course, is known for its interlocking Csâ€”and this reminded the Princess of Wales too much of Charles and Camilla. Because of Chanel's iconic logo, Diana â€œcould no longer bring herselfâ€ to wear the brand, People reported. Princess Diana wearing Chanel earlier in her royal life. Getty After marrying in 1981, Charles and Diana separated in 1992 and finalized their divorce in 1996â€”just one year before her untimely death. Though she had worn Chanel tweed suits early in her royal life, after her divorce, Diana couldn't wear Chanel because, as Australian designer Jayson Brundson told Harper's Bazaar, â€œShe said, 'No, I can't wear linked Cs, the double C.â€ Brundson styled Diana for a hospital charity event during what would ultimately become her last visit Down Under in 1996. After choosing a pair of Chanel shoes to compliment her cream Versace skirt suit, Diana demurred at wearing them. â€œI asked why, and she said, 'It's Camilla and Charles,'â€ Brundson recalled. Princess Diana in Sydney, Australia on November 1, 1996. Getty Princess Diana in Versace on October 31, 1996 in Sydney, Australia. Getty â€œIt was definitely the timing, it being post-divorce,â€ he continued. â€œShe would have seen linked Cs, and they would have just reminded her of Charles and Camilla. The shoes were quite boldly Chanelâ€”I think they had gold linked Cs on them. And I think for photo optics, people would have honed in on that considering it was so fresh after the divorce, as well.â€ Adding insult to injury, during her marriage to Charles, Diana found a pair of cufflinks Charles owned engraved with interlocked Csâ€”which she interpreted as an homage to Charles and Camilla. â€œIt's hard to believe that anyone as intelligent and well-read as the Prince of Wales could be so stupidâ€”so utterly incapable of imagining what a new wife might conclude if her husband carried a photograph of his old girlfriend in his diary,â€ royal biographer Penny Junor wrote in her biography of Camilla called The Duchess: The Untold Story. Princess Diana in Chanel earlier in her royal life. Getty Speaking to Andrew Morton for his bombshell 1992 biography about her called Diana: Her True Story, Diana recalled Charles sending Camilla flowers with a signed card reading â€œTo Gladys from Fredâ€â€”their nicknames for one another. â€œ[I met her] very early on,â€ Diana said of Camilla (via People). â€œI was introduced to the circle, but obviously I was a threat. I was a very young girl, but I was a threat. We always had discussions about Camilla, though. I once heard him on the telephone in his bath on his handheld set saying, 'Whatever happens, I will always love you.' I told him afterwards that I had listened at the door, and we had a filthy row.â€ About two weeks before their wedding on July 29, 1981, someone in Charles's office told Diana that he had a bracelet made for Camilla with â€œGâ€ and â€œFâ€ (for Gladys and Fred) intertwined on it. â€œI was devastated,â€ Diana said. Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer after their wedding ceremony at St. Paul's Cathedral on July 29, 1981. / Fox Photos / Hulton Archive â€œSo I had lunch with my sisters and said, 'I can't marry him, I can't do this, this is absolutely unbelievable,'â€ Diana recalled. â€œThey were wonderful and said, 'Well, bad luck Duch [Diana's childhood nickname], your face is on the tea towels, so you're too late to chicken out.' So we made light of it.â€ Diana added that, on their honeymoon, she noticed cufflinks on her husband's wristsâ€”â€œTwo Cs entwined like the Chanel Cs,â€ she said. â€œGot it in one; knew exactly. ' Camilla gave you those, didn't she?'...
